Problem:
Consider a partial differential equation (PDE) given by \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = L(u)\\), where \\(L\\) is a linear differential operator on function \\(u(x, t)\\). To analyze the system's behavior, we explore the effect of applying Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) to \\(u(x, t)\\), particularly focusing on the transformation over time.

Given the Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}[u](k, T)\\) at time T, can we uniquely determine the initial condition \\(u(x, 0)\\) without knowing whether the Fourier transform was applied at the beginning or at a later time?
Explanation: If the linear operator \\(L\\) leads to a well-posed PDE and the Fourier transform properties are preserved, inverse Fourier transform applied to \\(\\mathcal{F}[u](k, T)\\) will uniquely determine the initial condition by reversing the time evolution in the transform space and applying the inverse transform, regardless of the transformation timing.
